title: Les Fredette’s Crucifixion Nail: Why I am Skeptical About It
post:
Dan,
What an excellent essay on the process of observation. I reserve my judgment on many claims of things observed on the Shroud because those things that are observed and are beyond reasonable dispute are convincing enough of its authenticity. I think making the most recent photographs of very high definition available would be helpful in resolving some of the “sightings.” 
http://johnklotz.blogspot.com
author: John Klotz

title: Les Fredette’s Crucifixion Nail: Why I am Skeptical About It
post: Very well written, Dan.  I am of the opinion of Ray Rogers through Barrie Schwortz (I would have loved to have met Ray, I think I would have really liked him, but his death was far before I got involved in SEAM and created the website, which caused me to start my own study in 2009).  There has to be objective criteria by which to verify these observations to something provable by actual measurement.  I don’t pretend to know how that could be done for that is not my area, but it seems to me that experts in that area might come up with something.  Necessity is the mother of invention.
author: Andy Weiss

Dan,
How long will you ignore the alternative aspect to the sight-and-brain issue namely THINKING YOU DON’T SEE what is really there (as it does need a truly initiated eye/a strict & relevant methodology and presentation to be seen/detected)? How long will you just mantra your same old biased stuff after Murra and Di Lazzaro who most unscientifically too totally ignore the same alternative in their paper?

post: With respect, Max, I think I see on a photo of the Shroud is absurd.  Stuff can happen with any photo so to rely upon this is not really reliable without objective verification of the “think I see.”  I completely agree with Barrie Schwortz on this.
author: Andy Weiss
